importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred during a recent period, with the most intense rains reported on Wednesday, indicating a short but critical timeframe of environmental disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The death toll includes 29 in Veracruz, 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
65 people remain missing, with 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
Heavy rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military personnel, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist with search, rescue, food, and water distribution.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply in the affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
Early estimates show about 100,000 houses have been affected, with some structures nearly 'disappeared' near rivers.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the situation during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating the severity of the rain.
Governors and military units are coordinating efforts across the affected states to manage the disaster response.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has experienced severe flooding across five states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricanes Priscilla and Raymond, resulting in 64 confirmed deaths and 65 people still missing. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with over 280mm of rain. The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC), led by Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death toll and missing persons during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to provide food, clean water, and emergency assistance, while nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply. The government acknowledged that no prior warnings indicated such extreme rainfall, raising questions about early alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
